article.h_title: How to calculate your safety stock?
article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: In todayâ€™s volatile and uncertain world, stock management has become strategic for companies. It represents a key lever to mitigate risks, optimise inventory costs and ensure customer satisfaction. To cope with changes and uncertainties, many companies maintain consistent safety stock in their warehouses. The challenge lies in knowing how to effectively calculate safety stock, using precise formulas, and implementing the right optimisation strategies for procurement.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Safety stock, also known as buffer stock, refers to an additional inventory level held by a company to deal with unforeseen circumstances. This safety stock is set aside for emergency situations.

A delivery delay or a spike in demand can quickly prevent the smooth flow of the supply chain. Optimal safety stock allows precisely for preventing potential stockouts related to such uncertainties, without tying up too much capital. This helps avoid potential damages to the company such as customer dissatisfaction, decreased turnover, or additional costs.

There are two main types of uncertainties that can impact stock levels:
Supply-related uncertainties such as delivery delays, nonconforming goods, production issuesâ€¦
Demand-related uncertainties such as unexpected or seasonal spikes in demand, orders from a major customerâ€¦

Mehdi Kharab, co-founder and Chief Revenue Officer of Colibri, a Sales & Operations Planning solution, reminds us that effective stock management relies on two key elements: "To have the right stock, in the right place, at the right time, a factual and rigorous methodology combined with an efficient stock management tool are the best allies."

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Within a company, not all products necessarily need safety stock, or the same level of safety stock. Before even calculating safety stock, itâ€™s crucial to determine which products will be concerned. Otherwise, this safety stock can cause extra stock in the warehouse and generate unnecessary holding costs.

content.text: Paretoâ€™s law, or the 80/20 rule, considers that 80% of the overall value is produced by 20% of the most important units. In our case, this means that safety stock should be maintained for 20% of the products that represent 80% of the total value.

content.text: All safety stock is influenced by different variables: Fluctuations in demand, supplier lead timesâ€¦ Regardless of the method and mathematical formula chosen to calculate safety stock, these variables must be determined.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Lead time indicates the time in days required to receive a new order after placing it. This includes processing, production, and delivery time. This time can vary depending on several factors, notably geographical distance and supplier reliability.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Each company sets objectives in terms of customer service levels. However, this variable depends on the commercial policy, the type of products sold, and the business sector. Service quality is characterised by a companyâ€™s ability to meet customer demand, i.e. customer expectations.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Consumption is sometimes unpredictable and difficult to control, despite accurate demand forecasts. Demand volatility is amplified by competition, market effervescence, etc. And thatâ€™s without counting product seasonality. This is why it can be wise to calculate demand variability based on the standard deviation or coefficient of historical sales data variation.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: There are several possible methods for calculating safety stock, of which we will detail the workings and mathematical safety stock formulas. Today, many companies calculate their safety stock automatically, using specialised software.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text:
The company knows its average sales and decides to rely on its experience to determine a reasonable period that should be covered by its safety stock.
Safety stock = average sale x period to be covered by safety stock

article.h_title: The average and maximum safety stock formula
article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text:
The company refers to sales variations observed in the past and decides to apply a method that will allow it to respond to the same trends.
Safety stock = (maximum sale x maximum delivery time) - (average sale x average delivery time)

The normal distribution, or Gaussian distribution, applies when sales volumes are larger. This method allows for quite precise estimates in relation to a normal distribution of demand, to which uncertainties regarding demand and/or lead times are integrated, whether they are independent or not.
To apply this method, you should first define:
Your safety coefficient based on the desired service rate;
The standard deviations of your sales and supplies.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Safety stock = safety coefficient x standard deviation of sales x square root of average delivery time

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Safety stock = safety coefficient x average sales x standard deviation of delivery times

article.h_title: When demand and lead times are uncertain and independent
article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Safety stock = safety coefficient x square root ((average delivery time x (standard deviation of sales)Â²) + (average sales x standard deviation of delivery times)Â²)

article.h_title: When demand and lead times are uncertain and dependent
article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Safety stock = (safety coefficient x standard deviation of sales x square root of average delivery time) + (safety coefficient x average sales x standard deviation of delivery times)

article.h_title: Best practices to go even further
article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: To further optimise stock management, there are several strategies well known to logistics professionals.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text:
After calculating your safety stock, it is crucial to determine your reorder point, or replenishment point. This serves to define at what minimum stock level (alert stock) the company should trigger replenishment procedures. This action occurs before dipping into the safety stock.
To calculate the reorder point, use the formula below:
Reorder point = (average sale x average delivery time) + safety stock

article.h_title: Equipping yourself with a warehouse management system

content.text: Stockouts can sometimes be linked to poor management of stock data within the company itself. To facilitate stock management, a WMS (Warehouse Management System) solution can really make a difference. These tools allow you to accurately obtain recorded stock data as well as the location of products in the warehouse.

article.main_title: How to calculate your safety stock?

content.text: Companies also have every interest in establishing solid relationships with their suppliers to reduce replenishment times and their variability. Partnership agreements and constant communication allow for better forecasting of potential problems and proactive stock adjustment.
